question:
Which of the following options is the legislative organ of the Union government?

SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Legislative organ is responsible for making laws.
  • At the Union level, this power lies with the Parliament.
  • The Parliament includes the Lok Sabha, Rajya Sabha, and the President.
  • It is a bicameral legislature.
  • Other options like Judiciary and Executive perform different functions (law interpretation and implementation respectively).

Additional Points:

  • Lok Sabha members are directly elected.
  • Rajya Sabha is a permanent body with staggered elections.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a device of parliamentary proceedings?

SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
option_1: Half- an- hour discussion
solution:
• The Indian Parliament uses specific tools to raise issues and hold the government accountable.
  • Zero Hour and Half-an-hour discussions are recognized informal and formal mechanisms respectively.
  • Short duration discussions (commonly up to two hours) are allowed under Rule 193 in Lok Sabha.
  • Full-day discussion is not an official device listed in parliamentary rules.
  • It may happen in practice, but it's not a formally recognized procedure.

Additional Points:

  • Devices like Calling Attention, Adjournment Motion, and Question Hour are also formal mechanisms.
  • Discussions follow structured rules to ensure parliamentary discipline.

question:
Who has the power to regulate the right of citizenship in India?

SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Constitution of India (Article 11) empowers the Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship.
  • Though Articles 5 to 10 define citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution, future regulation is handled by Parliament.
  • This includes making laws related to acquisition, termination, and other aspects of citizenship.
  • The President only performs duties as per laws made by Parliament.
  • Neither the Supreme Court nor the Governor have any legislative authority in this matter.

Additional Points:

  • The Citizenship Act, 1955 was passed by Parliament under Article 11.
  • Amendments to this Act, such as CAA 2019, are also made by Parliament.

question:
The parliamentary standing committees have a tenure of _____ years.

SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (3rd shift)

Which of the following statements are correct regarding State Legislatures?

A. Notwithstanding anything in part XVII, but subject to the provisions of Article 348, business in the Legislature of a State shall be transacted in the official language or languages of the State or in Hindi or in English.

B. The Speaker of the Legislative Assembly or Chairman of the Legislative Council can permit any member to speak in his mother tongue.

C. Only the Supreme Court is entitled to inquire into the proceedings of the State Legislature.

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (2nd shift)
option_1: B and C only
option_3: A, B and C
option_4: A and B only
solution:
• Statement A is correct: As per Article 210(1) of the Constitution, business in the State Legislature can be conducted in the official language of the State, Hindi, or English, subject to Article 348.
  • Statement B is correct: Under Article 210(2), the Speaker/Chairman may allow a member to speak in his/her mother tongue with permission.
  • Statement C is incorrect: Courts, including the Supreme Court, are barred under Article 212 from inquiring into proceedings of the Legislature related to procedural irregularities.

Additional Points:

  • Article 212 protects legislative procedure from judicial interference.
  • State legislatures may have one or two houses, similar to the Parliament.

question:
In which year was the Jammu and Kashmir Legislative Council abolished?

Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• The Jammu and Kashmir Legislative Council, the upper house of the erstwhile state legislature, was abolished in 2019.
  • This action was part of the Jammu and Kashmir Reorganisation Act, 2019, which reorganized the state into two union territories: Jammu & Kashmir and Ladakh.
  • The Council, established in 1957, ceased to exist on 31 October 2019, coinciding with the official implementation of the reorganization .
  • The abolition aimed to streamline the legislative process by transitioning from a bicameral to a unicameral legislature in the new union territory of Jammu and Kashmir.

Additional Points:

  • The Jammu and Kashmir Reorganisation Act, 2019 was passed by the Indian Parliament in August 2019 and received presidential assent on 9 August 2019 .
  • The move also involved the abrogation of Article 370, revoking the region's special status.

question:
How many Members of Parliament were elected to the 17th Lok Sabha from Odisha?

Matriculation Level 24/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• Odisha has 21 Lok Sabha constituencies, each electing one Member of Parliament.
  • In the 2019 general elections, these 21 MPs were elected to the 17th Lok Sabha.
  • The Biju Janata Dal (BJD) secured 12 seats, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won 8 seats, and the Indian National Congress (INC) secured 1 seat.
  • Notably, Chandrani Murmu from Keonjhar became the youngest MP in the 17th Lok Sabha.

Additional Points:

  • The 17th Lok Sabha was constituted in 2019 and continued until 2024.
  • Odisha's representation in the Lok Sabha remained at 21 seats during this period.

question:
One-third of the members of the State Legislature Council retire every _____years.

Matriculation Level 24/06/2024 (Shift-4)
solution:
• The State Legislative Council is a permanent body, similar to the Rajya Sabha at the Centre.
  • It cannot be dissolved, but one-third of its members retire every 2 years.
  • This retirement system ensures continuity in the council's functioning.
  • Each member of the council serves a six-year term.
  • Elections are conducted at regular intervals to fill the retiring positions.

Additional Points:

  • States like Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Telangana, and Andhra Pradesh have Legislative Councils.
  • The Council consists of indirectly elected members from various categories (MLAs, graduates, teachers, etc.).
  • Provision for creation or abolition of a Legislative Council is given under Article 169 of the Constitution.

question:
When a non-minister proposes a bill, it is called:

Higher Secondary 20/06/2024 (Shift-2)
solution:
• In Parliament, a bill is a proposal for a new law or an amendment to an existing law.
  • When a non-minister MP (i.e., a member not part of the government/executive) introduces a bill, it is called a Private Member’s Bill.
  • In contrast, a Government Bill is introduced by a minister.
  • Private Member’s Bills highlight public issues and may propose reforms, though they rarely become law.
  • These bills are usually discussed only on Fridays when the Parliament is in session.

Additional Points:

  • The first successful Private Member’s Bill was the Muslim Wakf Validating Act, 1954.
  • Only 14 Private Member’s Bills have become laws since independence (as of 2023).
  • Private Members are given prior notice to introduce such bills (one month in advance).

question:
How many Lok Sabha seats are there for the state of Meghalaya?

Higher Secondary 21/06/2024 (Shift-2)
solution:
• Meghalaya has 2 Lok Sabha seats, which are:
    • Shillong (ST)
    • Tura (ST)
  • Both constituencies are reserved for Scheduled Tribes (ST) candidates.
  • This allocation has been consistent since the state's formation in 1972.

Additional Points:

  • In the 2024 general elections, the winners were:
    • Shillong: Ricky AJ Syngkon (Voice of the People Party)
    • Tura: Saleng A. Sangma (Indian National Congress)
  • Meghalaya also has 1 Rajya Sabha seat and a 60-member Legislative Assembly.

question:
Who was the first speaker of the Lok Sabha after India’s Independence?

Higher Secondary 21/06/2024 (Shift-2)
solution:
• The Speaker of the Lok Sabha is the presiding officer of the lower house of Parliament.
  • Ganesh Vasudev Mavalankar was the first Speaker of the Lok Sabha after independence.
  • He served from 1952 to 1956, during the First Lok Sabha.
  • Prior to that, he was the Speaker of the Constituent Assembly (Legislative).
  • Mavalankar is known as the "Father of Lok Sabha" for his pioneering role in shaping parliamentary procedures.

Additional Points:

  • After Mavalankar’s death in 1956, M.A. Ayyangar became the second Speaker.
  • The Speaker is elected by members of the Lok Sabha and holds office until the dissolution of the house.

question:
Which of the following options is INCORRECT?

In order to become a member of Vidhan Sabha, a person must:

Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift-4)
option_1: have his/her name in the voters’ list
option_2: have attained the age of 21 years
option_3: be a citizen of India
option_4: not hold any office of profit
solution:
• To become a member of the Vidhan Sabha (State Legislative Assembly), a person must meet certain constitutional requirements.
  • The minimum age to contest Vidhan Sabha elections is 25 years, not 21. Hence, option (b) is incorrect.
  • Other valid conditions include:
    • Name must be in the electoral roll of any constituency (✔️ option a).
    • Must be a citizen of India (✔️ option c).
    • Should not hold an office of profit under the government (✔️ option d).

Additional Points:

  • These qualifications are laid down in Article 173 of the Constitution.
  • Disqualifications are governed by Article 191 and Representation of the People Act, 1951.

question:
How many state Legislative Council members are elected by graduates of three years’ standing and residing within the state?

Higher Secondary 26/06/2024 (Shift-2)
solution:
• The composition of the State Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad) is defined in Article 171 of the Constitution.
  • It specifies how members are elected from various categories.
  • 1/12 of the members are elected by graduates of at least three years’ standing who reside in the state.
  • Other categories include teachers, MLAs, local authorities, and nominees of the Governor.

Additional Points:

  • Graduate constituency members represent educated citizens and are elected through a separate voter list.
  • Only states with bicameral legislatures (like Maharashtra, UP) have such provisions.

question:
Members of the Rajya Sabha are elected for a term of how many years?

Graduate Level 21/06/2024 (Shift-3)
solution:
• Rajya Sabha is the Upper House of the Indian Parliament and a permanent body.
  • Its members are elected for a term of 6 years.
  • One-third of its members retire every two years, and elections are held to fill those seats.
  • Members are elected by the elected members of State Legislative Assemblies through proportional representation.

Additional Points:

  • There is no dissolution of the Rajya Sabha unlike the Lok Sabha.
  • The Vice President of India is the ex-officio Chairman of the Rajya Sabha.

question:
Who elects the Presiding Officer (the Speaker) in the State legislature?

Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift-3)
option_2: Members of Vidhan Sabha
option_3: Member of Vidhan Parishad
solution:
• The Speaker is the Presiding Officer of the State Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha).
  • He/She is elected by the members of the Vidhan Sabha from among themselves.
  • This election usually takes place soon after the formation of a new assembly.
  • The Speaker conducts proceedings, maintains order, and ensures discipline in the House.
  • The Speaker holds office till the dissolution of the Assembly or resignation/removal.

Additional Points:

  • The Deputy Speaker is also elected by the Vidhan Sabha members.
  • The Speaker can cast a deciding vote (casting vote) in case of a tie.

question:
The first hour of a sitting of the House allotted for asking and answering of questions is called as __________.

SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The first hour of every parliamentary sitting is known as the Question Hour.
  • During this time, members ask questions to ministers regarding government functioning and policies.
  • It is considered an essential tool for ensuring accountability of the Executive to the Legislature.
  • Questions can be starred, unstarred, or short notice, each with different answering formats.
  • Ministers are obligated to respond, making it a key part of parliamentary oversight.

Additional Points:

  • Question Hour is followed by Zero Hour, which is not officially scheduled.
  • Question Hour is regulated by Rules of Procedure and Conduct of Business in both houses.

question:
A money bill under Article 111 of the Constitution of India, presented to the President for assent, has to be endorsed by a Certificate of the ________ signed by him/her that it is a money bill.

SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Evening)
option_1: Secretary General of the Lok Sabha
option_2: Secretary General of the Rajya Sabha
option_3: Speaker of the Lok Sabha
option_4: Deputy Chairman of the Rajya Sabha
solution:
• As per Article 110 of the Constitution, a Money Bill deals with matters like taxation, government spending, borrowing, etc.
  • When such a bill is passed by the Lok Sabha, it must carry a certificate stating that it is a Money Bill.
  • This certificate is signed by the Speaker of the Lok Sabha and is final and binding.
  • Under Article 111, the bill is then presented to the President for assent.
  • The Rajya Sabha has limited power in Money Bill matters—it can only suggest amendments but cannot reject it.

Additional Points:

  • The President cannot return a Money Bill for reconsideration.
  • The Speaker’s certification cannot be challenged in court.

question:
After how many days of absence from Parliament without permission will a Member of Parliament be disqualified?

SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• According to Article 101(4) of the Indian Constitution, a Member of Parliament (MP) can be disqualified if they remain absent for 60 consecutive days without permission.
  • This applies to both the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha.
  • The House must declare the seat vacant through a resolution.
  • The 60 days exclude days when the House is not in session.
  • This provision ensures MPs remain accountable and actively participate in legislative duties.

Additional Points:

  • The Speaker (Lok Sabha) or Chairman (Rajya Sabha) has the authority to grant leave of absence.
  • If no permission is granted, the member’s seat can be declared vacant.

question:
What is the bicameral legislature of the Indian Constitution?

SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Evening)
option_1: It is a legislative body with four houses.
option_2: It is a legislative body with two houses.
option_3: It is a legislative body with one house.
option_4: It is a legislative body with three houses.
solution:
• The term bicameral legislature refers to a legislative body with two houses.
  • In India, the Parliament is bicameral and consists of:

    • Lok Sabha (Lower House)

    • Rajya Sabha (Upper House)

  • This structure allows for checks and balances, better scrutiny of bills, and broader representation.
  • Some states like UP, Maharashtra, Karnataka also have bicameral legislatures at the state level.

Extra Insights:

  • Bicameralism is derived from the British parliamentary model.
  • Not all Indian states follow this system—most have unicameral legislatures.

question:
What is the most powerful weapon that enables the Parliament to ensure executive accountability?

SSC MTS 04/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
option_1: Approval or refusal of laws
solution:
• The No-Confidence Motion is the strongest tool in the hands of Parliament to ensure executive accountability.
  • It can only be moved in the Lok Sabha, where the Council of Ministers is collectively responsible.
  • If passed by a majority, the government is compelled to resign.
  • This mechanism upholds the principle that the Executive must enjoy the confidence of the majority in the House.
  • It reflects the essence of parliamentary democracy.
  • Extra Insights:
  • Minimum 50 members must support a no-confidence motion for it to be admitted.
  • This motion cannot be moved in the Rajya Sabha.

question:
What is the maximum time gap between two sessions of the State Legislature?

SSC MTS 08/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• As per Article 174(1) of the Constitution, the maximum time gap between two sessions of the State Legislature is six months.
  • This ensures that the Legislature meets at least twice every year.
  • The Governor is responsible for summoning the sessions, on the advice of the Council of Ministers.
  • This rule applies to both Houses (if bicameral) or the Legislative Assembly (if unicameral).

Extra Insights:

  • Exceeding a 6-month gap is a violation of the Constitution.
  • Common sessions include Budget, Monsoon, and Winter.

question:
When was the first general election for Lok Sabha held in India?

SSC MTS 11/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The first general election for Lok Sabha in India was held during 1951–52.
  • It was a historic milestone, marking the beginning of electoral democracy in independent India.
  • The Election Commission of India, established in 1950, conducted the election.
  • Voting took place from October 1951 to March 1952 across different phases.
  • Around 173 million (17.3 crore) people were eligible to vote, and first-time voters formed a large portion.
  • This was the world’s largest democratic election at that time.

Extra Insights:

  • Indian National Congress secured 364 out of 489 seats, forming the first government under Jawaharlal Nehru.
  • Ganesh Vasudev Mavalankar became the first Speaker of the Lok Sabha.
  • Constituencies were both single-member and multi-member in that election.
  • The success of the election surprised many global observers, proving India’s commitment to democracy.

question:
How long can a person remain a minister without being a member of either House of the State Legislature?

SSC MTS 12/09/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• As per Article 164(4) of the Indian Constitution, a person can be appointed as a minister in a state even if they are not a member of the State Legislature at the time of appointment.
  • However, such a person must get elected to either the Legislative Assembly or Legislative Council within 6 months.
  • If they fail to do so, they must resign from the ministerial post.
  • This provision ensures flexibility in leadership while maintaining democratic accountability.

Extra Insights:

  • The same 6-month rule also applies to the Union Council of Ministers under Article 75(5).
  • Famous example: Dr. Manmohan Singh was appointed Finance Minister in 1991 and elected to Rajya Sabha within 6 months.
  • This clause allows technocrats or non-elected individuals to temporarily take office in urgent situations.

question:
Which of the following pairs is/are correctly matched regarding the terminology used in the Parliament?

A. Appropriation Bill- A Money Bill passed for providing for the withdrawal or appropriation from and out of the Consolidated Fund of India

B. Demand for Grants- Earmarking of budgetary allocation for meeting only planned expenditure of a Ministry/Department

C. Short Duration Discussion- For raising a discussion on a matter of urgent public importance for which a notice has to be given by a Member and supported by 50 Members.

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (4th shift)
option_1: A, B and C
option_2: B and C only
solution:
• Statement A – Correct:

    The Appropriation Bill is a Money Bill introduced after the passage of Demand for Grants. It authorizes withdrawal of funds from the Consolidated Fund of India to meet government expenditure.

    Correctly matched.

  • Statement B – Incorrect:

    Demand for Grants refers to the total expenditure (planned + non-planned) requested by a Ministry/Department and is presented in the Lok Sabha. It is not limited only to planned expenditure.

    Incorrect match.

  • Statement C – Incorrect:

    A Short Duration Discussion (under Rule 193 in Lok Sabha) is raised on matters of urgent public importance, but it does not require support of 50 members. That condition applies to Adjournment Motions, not Short Duration Discussions.

    Incorrect match.

Extra Insights:

  • Appropriation Bill must be passed before withdrawing any money from the Consolidated Fund.
  • Short Duration Discussions allow members to discuss serious issues without voting.
  • Budgetary provisions are classified into charged and voted expenditures.

question:
Which of the following can make provisions for Ancillary powers of the Supreme Court?

SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (1st shift)
option_2: Law Commission of India
option_3: Minister of Law & Justice
solution:
• The Supreme Court of India derives its powers and functions from the Constitution.
  • According to Article 138 and 140, the Parliament has the authority to make laws to supplement the powers of the Supreme Court.
  • These ancillary powers refer to powers necessary for the effective functioning of the Court beyond what is explicitly stated.
  • Neither the President, Law Commission, nor the Law Minister can directly grant such powers — they can only recommend or advise.

Extra Insights:

  • Article 140 specifically allows Parliament to make laws for supplementary powers of the Supreme Court.
  • Ancillary powers help the Court enforce its jurisdiction and constitutional duties more efficiently.
  • These provisions ensure flexibility and adaptability in the judicial system.

question:
In India, during a meeting of the Legislative Assembly or Council, if there is no quorum, it shall be the duty of the ________ to adjourn the House or suspend the meeting.

Higher Secondary 27/06/2023 (Shift- 3)
solution:
• In legislative bodies like the Legislative Assembly or Legislative Council, a quorum is the minimum number of members required to conduct a meeting.
  • As per Article 189(4) of the Constitution (for State Legislatures), if quorum is not met, it is the Speaker (Assembly) or Chairman (Council) who must adjourn the House or suspend the meeting.
  • The quorum is one-tenth of the total membership of the House (excluding the presiding officer).
  • The meeting cannot proceed unless the quorum is fulfilled.

Extra Insights:

  • If a member notices lack of quorum, they can draw the attention of the presiding officer.
  • The Speaker or Chairman is bound by duty to take action once lack of quorum is established.
  • These rules ensure meaningful and valid legislative proceedings.

question:
A Money Bill should be returned to the Lok Sabha within ___ days by Rajya Sabha, either with recommendations or without recommendations.

SSC MTS 19/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• As per Article 110 and Article 109(5) of the Indian Constitution, a Money Bill is introduced only in the Lok Sabha.
  • Once passed by the Lok Sabha, it is sent to the Rajya Sabha for its recommendations.
  • The Rajya Sabha must return the Money Bill within 14 days, either with or without recommendations.
  • If Rajya Sabha does not return it within 14 days, the bill is deemed to have been passed by both Houses.
  • The Lok Sabha may accept or reject any or all of Rajya Sabha’s recommendations.

Extra Insights:

  • Rajya Sabha cannot amend or reject a Money Bill.
  • The Speaker of the Lok Sabha decides whether a bill is a Money Bill, and their decision is final.

question:
Archana wishes to contest for Lok Sabha elections in India. What is the maximum limit of constituencies that can she contest?

SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• As per Section 33(7) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, a person can contest elections from a maximum of two constituencies in the same general election.
  • This rule applies to both Lok Sabha and State Assembly elections.
  • Therefore, Archana can contest from up to two Lok Sabha constituencies, but not more.
  • If a candidate wins both seats, they must vacate one, leading to a by-election for the other.

Extra Insights:

  • Earlier, candidates could contest from more than two seats, but this was amended in 1996.
  • If a candidate vacates one seat, the cost of the by-election is borne by public funds.

question:
What is the term of the State legislative assembly in India as per Indian constitution?

SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• As per Article 172(1) of the Indian Constitution, the term of a State Legislative Assembly is 5 years from the date of its first sitting.
  • The Assembly can be dissolved earlier by the Governor on the advice of the Council of Ministers.
  • In case of a national emergency, Parliament can extend the term by one year at a time, but not beyond 6 months after the emergency ends.
  • The provision ensures stability and fixed tenure for democratic governance at the state level.

Extra Insights:

  • The term of 5 years is similar to that of the Lok Sabha.
  • Union Territories with legislatures (like Delhi and Puducherry) also follow the 5-year rule.

question:
The Lok Sabha (House of the People) was duly constituted for the first time on _______ .

SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The Lok Sabha, also known as the House of the People, was first constituted on 17 April 1952.
  • This followed the first general elections held in 1951–52, marking the beginning of India’s parliamentary democracy.
  • The first sitting of the 1st Lok Sabha took place on 13 May 1952.
  • The body was established under the provisions of the Constitution of India, which came into effect on 26 January 1950.

Extra Insights:

  • The first Lok Sabha had 489 constituencies.
  • Jawaharlal Nehru became the first Prime Minister to lead a government in the Lok Sabha.
  • Ganesh Vasudev Mavalankar was elected as the first Speaker of the Lok Sabha.

question:
Who runs the government at the national level under the parliamentary system?

SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
option_1: The President and Council of Ministers
option_2: The Prime Minister and Council of Ministers
solution:
• Under the parliamentary system in India, the real executive authority lies with the Prime Minister and the Council of Ministers.
  • The President is the nominal head (constitutional head), while the Prime Minister is the real head of government.
  • The Council of Ministers is collectively responsible to the Lok Sabha, and all executive powers are exercised in the name of the President but carried out by the ministers.
  • The Prime Minister leads the Council and decides the policies and direction of governance.

Extra Insights:

  • This setup is based on the British parliamentary model.
  • The Prime Minister is appointed by the President, but must have the majority support in the Lok Sabha.
  • The Council includes Cabinet Ministers, Ministers of State, and Deputy Ministers.

question:
The Constitution provides for reservation of seats in the Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies for the:

SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The Indian Constitution provides for the reservation of seats in the Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies for Scheduled Castes (SCs) and Scheduled Tribes (STs).
  • This provision is laid out in Articles 330 and 332.
  • It aims to ensure adequate political representation of historically disadvantaged communities.
  • The number of reserved seats is proportional to the population of SCs and STs in each state or union territory.
  • The reservation is periodically reviewed and extended through constitutional amendments.

Extra Insights:

  • Reservation for OBCs and women is not yet provided in legislatures through the Constitution (though the Women's Reservation Bill was passed in 2023 but implementation is pending).
  • The initial reservation was to last 10 years, but has been extended repeatedly through amendments.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a kind of question related to Indian Parliamentary Proceedings?

SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• In Indian Parliamentary Proceedings, members can ask questions to hold the government accountable.
  • There are three recognized types of questions:
    1. Starred Question – Requires an oral answer in the House and can be followed by supplementary questions.
    2. Unstarred Question – Requires a written answer; no supplementary questions allowed.
    3. Short Notice Question – Asked with less notice than the usual 10 days, regarding matters of urgent public importance.
  • There is no such category as "Long Notice Question" in official parliamentary procedure.

Extra Insights:

  • Starred questions are marked with an asterisk (*) and answered during Question Hour.
  • Short Notice Questions are allowed at the discretion of the Speaker/Chairman.
  • All questions must comply with rules laid down in the Rules of Procedure and Conduct of Business.

question:
Which of the following is called 'the temple of the country's democracy'?

SSC CPO 10/11/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• The Parliament of India is often referred to as the "temple of the country’s democracy".
  • It is the supreme legislative body of India, where elected representatives debate, deliberate, and make laws.
  • This term signifies the sacredness of democratic values and the importance of public representation.
  • The Parliament consists of the President, Lok Sabha, and Rajya Sabha.
  • The phrase emphasizes that people are the ultimate source of power, and their voice is heard through their representatives.

Extra Insights:

  • Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam and Prime Ministers like Narendra Modi have used this phrase to describe Parliament.
  • The Indian Parliament is located in New Delhi and was inaugurated in 1927.

question:
The state legislative assembly has a strength of ____, with exceptions for smaller states.

SSC MTS 06/07/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• As per Article 170 of the Indian Constitution, the strength of the State Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) shall not exceed 500 members and shall not be less than 60.
  • However, there are exceptions for smaller states like Sikkim, Goa, and Mizoram, which have fewer members due to their lower population.
  • The number of seats is based on population and area, as determined by Delimitation.
  • All members of the Legislative Assembly are directly elected by the people of the state.

Extra Insights:

  • Sikkim has 32, Goa has 40, and Mizoram has 40 Assembly seats.
  • The largest Vidhan Sabha is in Uttar Pradesh with 403 members.
  • The Governor summons and prorogues the sessions of the Assembly.

question:
According to the Indian Constitution, the House of People shall consist of not more than ______ members to represent the Union territories.

SSC MTS 12/07/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• As per Article 81 of the Indian Constitution, the Lok Sabha (House of the People) includes members representing States and Union Territories.
  • The Constitution specifies that the maximum number of members to represent Union Territories in the Lok Sabha shall not exceed 20.
  • These members are either directly elected or nominated depending on the status of the Union Territory.
  • The total strength of the Lok Sabha is 550, out of which up to 20 seats are allocated for Union Territories.

Extra Insights:

  • Delhi, Puducherry, Andaman & Nicobar, etc., elect MPs to the Lok Sabha.
  • The actual number of UT MPs may vary based on delimitation but can’t go beyond 20.

question:
How many organs of government are there according to the Indian Constitution?

SSC MTS 12/07/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• According to the Indian Constitution, the government is structured into three main organs:
    1. Legislature – Makes the laws (e.g., Parliament, State Legislatures).
    2. Executive – Implements the laws (e.g., President, Prime Minister, Council of Ministers).
    3. Judiciary – Interprets and enforces the laws (e.g., Supreme Court, High Courts).
  • This separation of powers ensures checks and balances among the organs and prevents misuse of power.

Extra Insights:

  • The concept of three organs is based on Montesquieu’s doctrine of separation of powers.
  • Though separate, in practice, India follows a system of interdependence and coordination between them.

question:
__________ is a motion moved by a member to cut short the debate on a matter before the House.

SSC MTS 13/07/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• Closure Motion is a parliamentary tool used to cut short or end the debate on a matter currently being discussed in the House.
  • It is moved by a member to urge the Speaker/Chairman to bring the discussion to a close and proceed to voting.
  • This motion helps in managing time and avoiding unnecessary delays in legislative business.
  • If accepted, the Speaker may put the pending question to vote without further discussion.

Extra Insights:

  • There are different types of closure like simple closure, closure by compartments, and guillotine (used for budget discussions).
  • The Speaker has full discretion to accept or reject the motion.

question:
According to the Indian Constitution, what is the tenure of the members of the State Legislative Council in India?

SSC MTS 14/07/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• As per the Indian Constitution, the tenure of members of the State Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad) is 6 years.
  • However, the Council is a permanent body and not subject to dissolution.
  • One-third of its members retire every 2 years, and elections are held to fill those vacancies.
  • This rotational system ensures continuity in the functioning of the Council.

Extra Insights:

  • The system is similar to the Rajya Sabha at the national level.
  • Members are elected from various categories: MLAs, teachers, graduates, local bodies, and gubernatorial nominations.

question:
Who has the power to abolish or create a legislative council in the state?

SSC MTS 18/07/2022 (Morning)
option_2: High court of the concerned State
option_4: Chief minister of the concerned state
solution:
• As per Article 169 of the Indian Constitution, the power to create or abolish a Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad) in a state lies with the Parliament of India.
  • The process begins when the State Legislative Assembly passes a resolution by a special majority (not less than two-thirds of members present and voting).
  • Once passed, the Parliament can make a law to create or abolish the Legislative Council in that state.
  • Neither the President, High Court, nor the Chief Minister has this power independently.

Extra Insights:

  • The creation/abolition of Legislative Councils is a flexible feature of the Constitution.
  • Only a few states in India have a bicameral legislature (e.g., UP, Bihar, Maharashtra).

question:
Which of the following is NOT a feature of parliamentary government in India?

SSC MTS 19/07/2022 (Evening)
option_1: Membership of the ministers in the legislature,
option_3: Presence of nominal and real executives
option_4: Collective responsibility of the executive to the legislature
solution:
• The Parliamentary system of government in India has several key features:
    1. Ministers are part of the legislature – they are either elected MPs or must get elected within 6 months.
    2. There is a nominal executive (President) and a real executive (Prime Minister and Council of Ministers).
    3. The Council of Ministers is collectively responsible to the Lok Sabha.
  • However, option (b) "Undissolvable lower house" is not a feature of the parliamentary system.
    1. The Lok Sabha (lower house) is not permanent; it can be dissolved before completing its 5-year term.
    2. This flexibility ensures accountability and political renewal when necessary.

Extra Insights:

  • Article 75(3) mandates collective responsibility of the executive to the Lok Sabha.
  • Article 83(2) provides for the dissolution of the Lok Sabha.
  • Parliamentary system promotes responsible government and ensures legislative control over the executive.

question:
An alliance formed by political parties after elections when no party has been able to get adequate seats to form a clear majority is called_____.

SSC MTS 20/07/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• When no single political party secures a clear majority in the legislature after elections, two or more parties may come together to form a government.
  • This arrangement is called a coalition.
  • The parties involved agree to share power and responsibilities, often based on a common minimum programme.
  • Coalition governments are common in multi-party democracies like India, especially at the central and state levels.

Extra Insights:

  • Famous example: The National Democratic Alliance (NDA) and United Progressive Alliance (UPA) at the national level.
  • Coalitions often lead to compromise politics and require strong coordination among parties.
  • This is different from appropriation (budget process) and prorogation (ending a parliamentary session).

question:
The period between prorogation of Parliament and re-assembly in a new session is called______.

SSC MTS 21/07/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The period between the prorogation of a session of Parliament and its reassembly in a new session is called a recess.
  • Prorogation refers to the formal end of a session by the President (on Cabinet’s advice).
  • During recess, Parliament is not in session, and no legislative business takes place.
  • This period is used by committees for internal work and allows the government to prepare for the next session.

Extra Insights:

  • Adjournment suspends the sitting for a short time (like hours or days), not the entire session.
  • Dissolution ends the Lok Sabha altogether; it applies only to the lower house.
  • Cut Motion is a tool to reduce allocations in budget demands, unrelated to sessions.

question:
In the absence of the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of Lok Sabha, who presides over the joint sitting of the two houses of Parliament?

SSC CHSL 24/05/2022 (Afternoon)
option_1: Chairman of Rajya Sabha
option_2: Any senior member of Rajya Sabha
option_3: Deputy Chairman of Rajya Sabha
option_4: Any senior member of Lok Sabha
solution:
• A joint sitting of both Houses of Parliament (Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha) is convened under Article 108 of the Constitution to resolve a legislative deadlock.
  • Normally, the Speaker of the Lok Sabha presides over this joint session.
  • If the Speaker is absent, the Deputy Speaker takes over.
  • If both are absent, then the Deputy Chairman of the Rajya Sabha presides.
  • The Chairman of Rajya Sabha (Vice President) does not preside over the joint sitting.

Extra Insights:

  • The joint sitting is usually held in the Lok Sabha chamber.
  • Only three bills have been passed through joint sitting: Dowry Prohibition Bill (1961), Banking Service Commission Repeal Bill (1978), and Prevention of Terrorism Bill (2002).

question:
The salary and allowances of leaders of opposition in parliament are governed by the Act passed for the first time by the parliament in the year ______.

SSC CGL 20/04/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The salary and allowances of the Leaders of Opposition in the Indian Parliament are governed by the Salary and Allowances of Leaders of Opposition in Parliament Act, 1977.
  • This Act was passed by Parliament in the year 1977 to provide legal recognition and ensure equivalent privileges to the recognized Leader of the Opposition as those given to a Cabinet Minister.
  • It applies to both Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha.

Extra Insights:

  • To qualify as the Leader of Opposition, a person must be from the largest opposition party with at least 10% of the total strength of the House.
  • The Leader of Opposition plays a key role in various statutory committees (e.g., for CBI Director appointment, Lokpal selection).
